abstracts.cdata!:
The Senegal Nutrition Enhancement
            Project II received a satisfactory outcome rating with
            moderate risk to development outcome. Both the Bank and the
            Borrower received satisfactory performance ratings. The
            project was restructured four times. The first time was in
            2008 to reallocate project funds within the project. About
            15 percent of the International Development Association
            (IDA) credit planned for purchase of pharmaceutical products
            and unallocated funds were reallocated to strengthen the
            community-based nutrition scale up (Component 1). The second
            restructuring, again for a reallocation of project funds,
            was conducted in 2011. The third restructuring was conducted
            in 2012 when an additional financing from IDA resources
            became available in March 2012. An extension of the project
            closing date by 13 months was approved. This additional
            financing and project extension made it possible to add a
            fifth PDO and adjust targets upwards that had already been
            achieved before time. New indicators to strengthen the
            response mechanisms for the protection of nutrition among
            vulnerable groups were also added and they reflected a
            stronger focus on: (i) anemia prevention; and (ii)
            multi-sectoral approaches at community level to reduce
            vulnerability to external shocks. The following lessons were
            gained from this project: (1) A shift in the nutrition
            discourse to move beyond emergency aid and therapeutic care
            of malnutrition into the objectives of poverty reduction and
            development is significant in establishing and sustaining
            partnerships with Local Governments and sectors infrequently
            engaging with health and nutrition. (2) The onset of
            different crises with serious economic consequences
            demonstrates the need to enhance household and community
            resilience. (3) Ten years of collaboration between the
            Government of Senegal and the Bank can improve
            sustainability of nutrition policy development. (4) Strong
            national leadership is fundamental to break the invisibility
            of nutrition and the fragmentation in the discourse
            surrounding it. (5) Fostering formal partnerships between
            Local Government, civil society, private sector and sector
            ministries at the operational level can contribute to the
            reduction of malnutrition. (6) CEAs characteristic of being
            flexible in producing innovative and inclusive forms of
            community mobilization is essential in gradually turning
            over the leadership to the local governments. (7) The
            subsidiarity principle has contributed to: (i) a lean
            management structure (and low overhead expenditures); and
            (ii) the development of local capacity among mothers,
            village leaders and Local Government. (8) Scaling-up
            nutrition interventions to reach 70 percent of the target
            population is possible through a community-based approach.
            (9) The package of direct nutrition interventions have been
            effective in reducing chronic malnutrition (linear growth
            retardation), but has done little in making a difference in
            the rate of acute malnutrition. (10) Effective communication
            for behavioral change and counseling requires specific
            messages on the promoted behaviors that build on positive examples.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Additional Financing for the
            Second Nutrition Enhancement Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Additional
            Financing for the Second Nutrition Enhancement Project for
            Senegal is to improve nutrition conditions of vulnerable
            populations, in particular those affecting growth of
            children under five in poor urban and rural areas. The
            additional credit will help implement modified and
            additional project activities which cannot be funded under
            the initial project, specifically: (i) the expansion of
            nutrition activities to scale up the project's impact
            and development effectiveness under component one
            (community-based nutrition) and component three (support for
            implementation, monitoring and evaluation of the nutrition
            development policy); and (ii) the financing gap for
            multisectoral pro-nutrition activities under component two
            (multisectoral support for nutrition).

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Nutrition Enhancement Second
            Phase Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Nutrition
            Enhancement Second Phase Project for Senegal is to expand
            access to and enhance nutritional conditions of vulnerable
            populations, in particular those affecting growth of
            children under five in poor urban and rural areas. The
            reallocation of the credit proceeds is needed to enhance
            project effectiveness by ensuring funding for the
            program's central component on sub-grants for community
            nutrition sub-projects. The reallocation aims to maintain
            the coverage and strengthen the intensity of the
            community-based activities, particularly in light of the
            negative impact of the external economic shocks on poverty
            and nutrition. The reallocation is made possible because of
            economies made on the categories of drugs and pharmaceutical
            supplies, consulting services and project management costs
            over the course of the project implementation, mainly as the
            result of new support from other donor sources and and/or
            increased Government contributions.  No changes are being
            made to the development objectives, outcomes, design, or
            scope of the project.
